Thomas, Stephen, and Zota

event.desc: Anastasius died in 518 (830 Alexander).
Justin became the new emperor upon Anastasius's death in 518 (830 Alexander).
Justin introduced the impious synod of Chalcedon. Those who did not assent, lived under persecution and exile. This began in the year 518 (830 Alexander).
The persecution reached Mare, Bishop of Amida in Mesopotamia and he chose exile over the synod of Chalcedon. He went into exile in Petra with Sergius, Stephen, and Thomas.

person.persName: Mare, Bishop of Amida in Mesopotamia

residence.note: Mare resided in Petra after the exile.
After the exile, Stephen resided in Petra.
After the exile, Thomas resided in Petra.
After the exile, Sergius resided in Petra.

relation.desc: Mara, metropolitan of Amid had ecclesiastical authority over Stephen, Thomas and Sergius.

event.desc: Mare sent Stephen to the Royal City to ask for relief from their distress in Petra. Stephen appealed to Theodora. She appealed to her husband Justinian. He appealed to his uncle, Justin I who stated that Mare could come to Alexandria.

relation.desc: Theodora, Roman empress and Justinian I were spouses.
Justin I, Justinian I and Theodora, Roman empress were part of the same household.

event.desc: Stephen delivered the order to come to Alexandria to Mare and his men as well as to Isidore, Bishop of Kenneshrin, also in exile.

Mare and his men found an old man who sold utensils for a living in the village of Mendis. He lived in a community of other religious exiles. Stephen and Thomas asked the man to lead them to the exiles.

person.persName: An old man who sold utensils and lived in exile in Mendis.

residence.note: Anonymous 3603 resided near the village of Mendis.

personGrp.persName: The men and women who lived in exile in Mendis

residence.note: Anonymi 3604 resided in exile near the village of Mendis.

event.desc: Thomas, endeavored to live as an ascetic in the pit near the village of Mendis, but everyone who heard of his plans laughed at him because he had such a privileged upbringing. He was a patrician who had his own estate and slaves and he was the descendent of the great patrician, Ishakuni Bar Brʿy.

socecStatus.note: Ishakuni Bar Brʿy was a patrician.

relation.desc: Thomas descended from Ishakuni Bar Brʿy.

event.desc: Stephen intended to live an ascetic life, but he was sickly and feeble of body.

trait.note: Stephen was sickly and feeble of body.

event.desc: Thomas gave his keys to The bishop's cellarer and snuck out of his monastery at night to go to the pit, where he lived an ascetic life of prayer and fasting.
After six years of living in the pit, Thomas's trials left him physically ill and infirm.
Mare died in Alexandria
Stephen and the sisters of Mare, Anonymous 3606 and Anonymous 3607, received permission from Theodora to take Mare's bones to his own country.

state.note: Anonymous 3606 was considered among the saints because of her mode of life.
Anonymous 3607 was considered among the saints because of her mode of life.

relation.desc: Mara, metropolitan of Amid, Anonymous 3606 and Anonymi 3607 were siblings.

event.desc: Mare's bones were put to rest in a chapel in Beth Shurla
Thomas went to the Monastery of John Urtaya, where his sister Cosmo found him and pleaded with him to come home. He refused and remained at the monastery.

Stephen saw that Thomas was residing in Monastery of John Urtaya and decided to join him, as did another monk who served under Mare, named Zota. All three men dwelled in the Monastery of John Urtaya for two years.

relation.desc: Mara, metropolitan of Amid had ecclesiastical authority over Zota.

residence.note: Thomas resided in the Convent of John Urtaya.
Zwtʾ resided in the Convent of John Urtaya.
Stephen resided in the Convent of John Urtaya.

event.desc: John of Ephesus, who was a monk in the Convent of John Urtaya, observed Thomas's ascetic practices and had many enlightening conversations with him.

residence.note: John resided in the Convent of John Urtaya.

event.desc: Thomas, Stephen, and Zwtʾ departed from the Convent of John Urtaya after two years and headed toward Egypt.
Theodora sent a letter to Stephen, inviting the monks to stay with her at court.

relation.desc: Theodora, Roman empress sent a letter to Stephen.

event.desc: Stephen accepted the invitation and tried to convince Thomas and Zwtʾ to accompany him, but they refused and parted ways. Thomas wished to dedicated the remainder of his life to fasting and praying alone in the desert.

John of Ephesus found Thomas and Zota years later in the desert of Mendis by Mar Menas. Thomas's body was frail and sunburnt. He had dedicated his life to fasting, praying, so that by depriving the body he would purify the soul.

residence.note: Thomas resided in the desert of Mendis.
Zwtʾ resided in the desert of Mendis.

event.desc: Thomas died.
Zwtʾ died after Thomas.
Stephen lived a life of asceticism and abstinence, setting an excellent example for the king, queen, and senators.
Stephen died.
